Alveolar Epithelial Cell.definition: Cells of the distal lung parenchyma. Includes AT1 (gas exchange, AGER+), AT2 (surfactant, SFTPC+), and transitional states.

Alveolar Type 1 Cell.definition: Large, squamous cells (AT1) that form the primary gas exchange surface of the alveoli.

Alveolar Type 2 Cell.definition: Cuboidal cells (AT2) that produce surfactant, modulate the alveolar immune response, and act as progenitors for AT1 cells.

Cycling Alveolar Type 2 Cell.definition: AT2 cells undergoing active proliferation, often in response to injury or for homeostasis.

Krt8 positive Alveolar Ductal Cell.definition: A transitional/progenitor state (also known as DATP or ADI) found at the alveolar-bronchiolar junction, especially during repair.

Alveolar Intermediate Cell.definition: A pathological transitional state (ATi) found in fibrosis, phenotypically intermediate between ATI/ATII cells and Aberrant Basaloid cells. Shares markers with both (e.g., GDF15, CTSE, CPA6) but lacks key basaloid markers (TP63-, KRT17-).

Aberrant Basaloid Cell.definition: A pathological epithelial cell state found in fibrosis (e.g., IPF), located at myofibroblast foci. Co-expresses basal (KRT17+, TP63+), mesenchymal (VIM+), and senescence (CDKN1A+) markers, but lacks KRT5.

Airway Epithelial Cell.definition: Cells of the conducting airways. A heterogeneous group including Basal (KRT5+), Ciliated (FOXJ1+), Club (SCGB1A1+), and Goblet (MUC5AC+) cells.

Basal Cell.definition: The primary stem cell of the proximal airways, responsible for self-renewal and differentiation into other luminal cell types.

Suprabasal Cell.definition: A transient, intermediate cell state migrating from the basal layer and committed to differentiation.

Secretory Primed Basal Cell.definition: A subpopulation of basal cells molecularly primed to assume secretory cell fates.

Secretory Cell.definition: Cells responsible for producing the protective airway mucus layer.

Club Cell.definition: The primary secretory cell of the smaller bronchioles, producing secretoglobins and acting as a progenitor.

Goblet Cell.definition: Secretory cells specializing in the production and secretion of gel-forming mucins (e.g., MUC5AC, MUC5B).

Differentiating Secretory Cell.definition: Cells in a transitional state, likely differentiating from basal or secretory progenitors into mature Club or Goblet cells.

Ciliated Cell.definition: Terminally differentiated cells with motile cilia, responsible for moving mucus and debris out of the airways (mucociliary clearance).

Differentiating Ciliated Cell.definition: Cells in the process of ciliogenesis, developing motile cilia.

Rare Airway Cell.definition: A collection of low-abundance, specialized airway epithelial cells.

Pulmonary Neuroendocrine Cell PNEC.definition: Chemosensory cells that release neuropeptides in response to airway stimuli.

Tuft Cell.definition: Chemosensory cells involved in type 2 immune responses, sensing allergens and parasites.

Ionocyte.definition: A rare cell type highly expressing the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) and regulating ion/fluid balance.

Mesenchymal Cell.definition: Stromal/connective tissue cells (VIM+). Includes Fibroblasts (DCN+), Smooth Muscle (ACTA2+), and Pericytes (RGS5+).

Fibroblast.definition: Connective tissue cells responsible for synthesizing and maintaining the extracellular matrix (ECM) of the lung.

Alveolar Fibroblast.definition: Fibroblasts residing in the alveolar interstitium, crucial for AT2 cell development (Lgr6+) and ECM homeostasis (Lgr5+).

Adventitial Fibroblast.definition: Fibroblasts located in the connective tissue surrounding large airways and blood vessels.

Myofibroblast.definition: A contractile, activated state of fibroblasts (e.g., ACTA2+, CTHRC1+) involved in wound healing and tissue remodeling. Can be pathogenic in fibrosis.

Invasive Fibroblast.definition: A pathological fibroblast state in IPF characterized by an invasive phenotype and expression of markers like HAS1, HAS2, and CXCL14.

Smooth Muscle Cell.definition: Contractile cells that regulate the diameter of airways and blood vessels.

Airway Smooth Muscle Cell.definition: Smooth muscle cells surrounding the conducting airways, regulating bronchomotor tone.

Vascular Smooth Muscle Cell.definition: Smooth muscle cells surrounding pulmonary arteries and veins, regulating vascular resistance and blood pressure.

Pericyte.definition: Mesenchymal cells that wrap around endothelial cells in capillaries and venules, crucial for vascular integrity and blood flow regulation.

Endothelial Cell.definition: Cells lining all blood and lymphatic vessels (PECAM1+). Includes distinct arterial, venous, capillary (gCap, aCap), peribronchial, and lymphatic subtypes.

Arterial Endothelial Cell.definition: Endothelial cells lining the pulmonary arteries and arterioles, adapted for high-pressure blood flow.

Venous Endothelial Cell.definition: Endothelial cells lining the pulmonary veins and venules.

Capillary Endothelial Cell.definition: The most abundant endothelial cells, forming the vast network of capillaries in the alveolar wall for gas exchange.

Alveolar Capillary Cell.definition: A highly specialized, thin capillary cell (aCap), also termed 'Aerocyte'. Adapted for efficient gas exchange with AT1 cells and leukocyte trafficking.

General Capillary Cell.definition: A thicker capillary cell (gCap) not specialized for gas exchange; functions as a progenitor for capillary homeostasis/repair and regulates vasomotor tone.

VWA1 positive PLVAP positive Ectopic End.definition: A pathological endothelial state, likely derived from capillary plasticity in fibrosis, characterized by VWA1 and PLVAP expression but lacking high COL15A1.

Peribronchial Endothelial Cell.definition: Endothelial cells of the systemic bronchial circulation, distinct from the pulmonary circulation. Marked by COL15A1, and ectopically expanded in fibrotic parenchyma.

Lymphatic Endothelial Cell.definition: Cells lining the lymphatic drainage vessels, crucial for fluid homeostasis and immune cell trafficking.

Mesothelial Cell.definition: Epithelial-like cells that form the pleura, the lining of the lung and chest cavity. Highly distinct markers (WT1+, MSLN+).

Chondrocyte.definition: Cartilage cells, primarily from the tracheal and bronchial rings. Highly distinct markers (COL2A1+, ACAN+). Very rare.

Neuronal Cell.definition: Cells of the nervous system that innervate the lung. Very rare, with markers like NRXN1.

Pulmonary Sensory Neuron.definition: Viscerosensory neurons (nodose-derived) that monitor the internal state of the lung.

Somatosensory Neuron.definition: Neurons (jugular-derived) involved in somatosory perception, such as nociception (cough).

Glial Cell.definition: Support cells for the nervous system, such as Schwann cells. Very rare, with markers like S100B, PLP1.

Alveolar Macrophage.definition: The large, tissue-resident macrophage population in the alveolar airspace. Typically CD68+, C1QA+, and uniquely PPARG+ / FABP4+.

Cycling Alveolar Macrophage.definition: Alveolar macrophages undergoing self-renewal through proliferation.

Monocyte and Dendritic Cell.definition: A challenging continuum of myeloid cells, including monocytes, interstitial macrophages, and rare dendritic cell subtypes. Best annotated together in the first pass and then sub-clustered for high-resolution separation.

Monocyte and Interstitial Macrophage.definition: A continuum of blood-derived monocytes (CD14+) and tissue-resident interstitial macrophages (CD68+, C1QA+, but PPARG-).

Monocyte.definition: Circulating myeloid cells that are recruited to the lung during inflammation and can differentiate into macrophages or dendritic cells.

CD14 positive Monocyte.definition: Classical monocytes, strongly expressing CD14, that are inflammatory and phagocytic.

CD16 positive Monocyte.definition: Non-classical monocytes, with high CD16 (FCGR3A) expression, that patrol the endothelium.

Interstitial Macrophage.definition: Macrophages residing in the lung tissue interstitium, often derived from circulating monocytes.

SPP1 positive Profibrotic Macrophage.definition: A disease-associated macrophage population, enriched in fibrosis (IPF) and characterized by high expression of SPP1, involved in fibrotic remodeling.

Dendritic Cell.definition: Antigen-presenting cells (APCs) with distinct subtypes: cDC1 (CLEC9A+), cDC2 (CD1C+), and pDC (LILRA4+, JCHAIN+).

Conventional DC1.definition: Dendritic cells specialized in cross-presenting antigens to CD8+ T cells.

Conventional DC2.definition: Dendritic cells specialized in priming CD4+ T cell responses.

Plasmacytoid DC.definition: Dendritic cells specialized in producing large amounts of type I interferon in response to viral infections.

Mast Cell.definition: A highly distinct myeloid cell population characterized by strong expression of KIT, CPA3, and TPSAB1.

Granulocytes.definition: Myeloid cells including Neutrophils, Eosinophils, and Basophils. Often rare in healthy tissue but identifiable by S100A8/A9 (Neutrophils).

Neutrophil.definition: A type of granulocyte involved in acute inflammation and bacterial defense.

Eosinophil.definition: A type of granulocyte involved in allergic responses and parasitic infections.

Basophil.definition: A rare type of granulocyte involved in allergic responses.

T Cell.definition: Adaptive lymphocytes defined by T-cell receptor expression (CD3D+, CD3E+). Includes CD4+, CD8+, and Regulatory T cell subtypes.

CD4 positive T Cell.definition: Helper T cells that coordinate immune responses by activating other immune cells (e.g., B cells, macrophages).

Naive CD4 positive T Cell.definition: Quiescent T cells that have not yet encountered their cognate antigen.

Memory CD4 positive T Cell.definition: Long-lived T cells that provide rapid, robust responses upon re-infection.

CD8 positive T Cell.definition: Cytotoxic T cells that directly kill virus-infected cells or tumor cells.

Naive CD8 positive T Cell.definition: Quiescent cytotoxic T cells that have not yet encountered their cognate antigen.

Memory CD8 positive T Cell.definition: Long-lived cytotoxic T cells that provide rapid, robust responses upon re-infection.

Cytotoxic CD8 positive T Cell.definition: Activated, effector cytotoxic T cells actively expressing cytotoxic molecules (e.g., Granzymes, Perforin).

Regulatory T Cell.definition: A subset of CD4+ T cells specialized in suppressing immune responses to maintain tolerance.

Gamma Delta T Cell.definition: A non-conventional T cell subset with a distinct T-cell receptor, often involved in tissue homeostasis and rapid responses.

NK and ILC Cell.definition: Innate lymphocytes lacking a T-cell receptor (CD3D-). Includes NK cells (NKG7+, KLRF1+) and ILCs (IL7R+, KIT+).

Natural Killer NK and NKT Cell.definition: Cytotoxic lymphocytes of the innate (NK) or adaptive-innate bridge (NKT) immune system.

NK Cell.definition: Innate cytotoxic lymphocytes that target virally infected or cancerous cells without prior sensitization.

NKT Cell.definition: A T-cell subset that co-expresses T-cell and NK-cell markers, bridging the innate and adaptive immune systems.

Innate Lymphoid Cell ILC.definition: Lymphoid cells that are part of the innate immune system and mirror the functions of T helper cells (e.g., ILC1, ILC2, ILC3).

ILC1.definition: ILCs that mirror Th1 cells, producing IFN-gamma in response to intracellular pathogens.

ILC2.definition: ILCs that mirror Th2 cells, producing IL-5 and IL-13 in response to allergens and helminths.

ILC3.definition: ILCs that mirror Th17 cells, producing IL-17 and IL-22, important for mucosal barrier defense.

B Cell.definition: Adaptive lymphocytes defined by B-cell receptor expression (CD79A+, MS4A1+).

Naive B Cell.definition: Quiescent B cells that have not yet encountered their cognate antigen.

Memory B Cell.definition: Long-lived B cells that provide rapid antibody responses upon re-infection.

Plasma Cell.definition: Terminally differentiated B cells, highly specialized for antibody secretion (JCHAIN+, SDC1+, XBP1+). Lack MS4A1.

Megakaryocyte and Erythroid.definition: Cells of hematopoietic origin that are not leukocytes. Includes Megakaryocytes (PF4+, PPBP+) and Erythroid cells (HBB+).

Megakaryocyte.definition: A unique, immune-active population of lung-resident megakaryocytes (MkL) capable of activating T cells.

Erythroid Cell.definition: Cells of the red blood cell lineage, often captured in lung tissue digests.
